problems.title: Souvlaki VS. Kalamaki
problems.statementHtml:
Two players, Souvlaki and Kalamaki, are given a sequence aa of nn integers.

They will play a game that consists of n−1n−1 rounds, which are numbered from 11 to n−1n−1. Souvlaki plays on odd-numbered rounds, and Kalamaki on even-numbered rounds.

On the ii-th round, a player can choose to take exactly one of the following actions:

Souvlaki wins if after the end of the last round, aa is sorted in non-decreasing order. In other words, he wins if ai≤ai+1ai≤ai+1 holds for every 1≤i<n1≤i<n. Otherwise, Kalamaki wins.

However, Souvlaki does not like losing, so before the start of the game, he may re-order the elements of aa in anyway he wants. Is it possible for him to do so such that he has a guaranteed winning strategy?
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1001≤t≤100). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer, nn (3≤n≤1003≤n≤100) — the number of integers in aa.

The second line contains exactly nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤n1≤ai≤n) — where aiai represents the ii-th element of aa.
problems.outputSpecHtml:
For each test case, output on a separate line "'YES"' if it is possible for Souvlaki to re-order the elements of aa such that he has a guaranteed winning strategy, and "'NO"' otherwise.

You can output the answer in any case (upper or lower). For example, the strings "'yEs"', "'yes"', "'Yes"', and "'YES"' will be recognized as positive responses.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first example, a=[4,2,2,1]a=[4,2,2,1]. A possible way to re-order the elements so that Souvlaki can win is the following: a=[2,1,2,4]a=[2,1,2,4]. Then, the game might go as follows:

  1. On round 11, it is Souvlaki's turn. He will choose to swap a1a1 with a2a2, and now a=[1,2,2,4]a=[1,2,2,4].
  2. On round 22, it is Kalamaki's turn. Whether he chooses to skip his turn or swap elements a2a2 and a3a3, aa will remain the same. Suppose he skips his turn.
  3. On round 33, it is Souvlaki's turn. He can choose to skip his turn as well, because if he swapped the last two elements he would lose.

After every round, a=[1,2,2,4]a=[1,2,2,4], sorted in non-decreasing order, so Souvlaki wins, no matter how Kalamaki chooses to play.

On the second example, since every element is equal, Souvlaki will always win because aa is always sorted in non-decreasing order.

problems.title: Siga ta Kymata
problems.statementHtml:
You are given a permutation∗∗ pp of every integer from 11 to nn. You also own a binary†† string ss of size nn where si=0si=0 for all 1≤i≤n1≤i≤n. You may do the following operation at most 55 times:

You are also given a binary string xx of size nn. After performing operations, it must hold for every 1≤i≤n1≤i≤n that if xi=1xi=1, then si=1si=1. Note that if xi=0xi=0, then sisi can have any value.

Figure out any sequence of at most 55 operations such that the aforementioned condition is satisfied, or report that it is impossible to do so. Note that you do not have to minimize the number of operations you make.

∗∗A permutation pp of every integer from 11 to nn is a sequence of elements from 11 to nn such that every element appears exactly once.

††A string bb of size mm is considered binary if and only if bi=0bi=0 or bi=1bi=1 for all 1≤i≤m1≤i≤m.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer nn (3≤n≤2⋅1053≤n≤2⋅105) — the size of the array.

The second line contains exactly nn integers p1,p2,…,pnp1,p2,…,pn (1≤pi≤n1≤pi≤n, the elements of pp are pairwise distinct) — where pipi is the ii-th element of the permutation.

The third line contains a single binary string xx of size nn.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml:
For each test case, if it is impossible to perform operations such that the constraint is satisfied, output −1−1.

Otherwise, output an integer 0≤k≤50≤k≤5, the number of operations. On the ii-th of the next kk lines, output two integers 1≤li≤ri≤n1≤li≤ri≤n, the bounds of the ii-th operation that is performed. If there are multiple correct solutions, output any of them.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first example, p=[1,2,3]p=[1,2,3], and x=010x=010. We can perform a single operation, with l=1l=1 and r=3r=3. After the operation, we set s2s2 to 11 since l<2<rl<2<r and min(pl,pr)<p2=2<max(pl,pr)min(pl,pr)<p2=2<max(pl,pr) hold at the same time. As a result, s=010s=010.

In the second example, it can be shown that there does not exist a correct sequence of at most 55 operations, so we output −1−1.

In the third example, p=[1,3,2,4,6,5]p=[1,3,2,4,6,5] and x=001100x=001100. After performing an operation for l=1l=1 and r=5r=5, then s=011100s=011100. If we also perform an operation for l=2l=2 and r=6r=6, then ss will remain the same. The string s=011100s=011100 is valid, because for every position where xx has a 11, then ss also has a 11 at that position.

problems.title: Monopati
problems.statementHtml:
You are given a grid a of 2 rows and n columns, where every cell has value from 1 to 2n.

Let f(l,r), where 1≤l≤r≤2n, represent a binary∗ grid b of 2 rows and n columns, such that bi,j=1 if and only if l≤ai,j≤r. Note that cell (i,j) denotes the cell i rows from the top and j columns from the left.

Count the number of pairs of integers (l,r) such that 1≤l≤r≤2n, and in f(l,r) there exists a down-right path of adjacent cells† with value of 1 from cell (1,1) to (2,n).

∗A grid is considered binary if and only if every cell of it has value of 0 or 1.

†A down-right path of adjacent cells is a sequence of cells such that each cell in the sequence shares either its top side or its left side with a side of the previous cell in the sequence.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases t (1≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer n (2≤n≤2⋅105) — the number of columns in the grid.

The second line contains exactly n integers a1,1, a1,2, ..., a1,n (1≤a1,i≤2n) — the values of the cells of the first row of the grid.

The third line contains exactly n integers a2,1, a2,2, ..., a2,n (1≤a2,i≤2n) — the values of the cells of the second row of the grid.

It is guaranteed that the sum of n across all test cases does not exceed 2⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For every test case, output on a separate line a single integer representing the number of pairs of integers (l,r) such that 1≤l≤r≤2n, and in f(l,r) there exists a down-right path of adjacent cells with value of 1 from cell (1,1) to (2,n).
problems.noteHtml:
Consider the first example.

The grids f(1,1),f(1,2) will look like the following:

10
01

There does not exist a path of 1s from the top-left cell to the bottom-right cell, therefore the pairs (1,1) and (1,2) are not counted.

The grids f(1,3) and f(1,4) will look like the following:

11
11

Since there exists a valid path from (1,1) to (2,2), the pairs (1,3) and (1,4) will be counted.

The grids f(2,2), f(4,4) will be the following:

00
00

The grids f(2,3), f(2,4), f(3,3), f(3,4) will look like the following:

01
10

So the pairs (2,3), (2,4), (3,3) and (3,4) will not be counted.

The only pairs counted where pairs (1,3) and (1,4), so the answer is 2.

problems.title: Diadrash (Easy Version)
problems.statementHtml:
This is the Easy version of the problem. The difference between the versions is that in this version, you can make at most max(300,⌈n2⌉+2)max(300,⌈n2⌉+2) queries. You can hack only if you solved all versions of this problem.

This problem is interactive.

There is a permutation∗∗ pp of the integers from 00 to n−1n−1 hidden from you. Additionally, you are given qq ranges [l1,r1],[l2,r2],…,[lq,rq][l1,r1],[l2,r2],…,[lq,rq] where 1≤li≤ri≤n1≤li≤ri≤n.

You need to discover the maximum MEXMEX among the values of pp in the qq ranges that are given to you in the input. Formally, you must discover the value of maxqi=1MEX([pli,pli+1,…,pri])maxi=1qMEX⁡([pli,pli+1,…,pri])††. To do this, you may make at most max(300,⌈n2⌉+2)max(300,⌈n2⌉+2) queries of the following form:

∗∗A permutation of the integers from 00 to n−1n−1 is a sequence of nn elements where every integer from 00 to n−1n−1 appears exactly once. For example, the sequence [0,3,1,2][0,3,1,2] is a permutation, but the sequence [0,0,2,1][0,0,2,1] is not.

††The MEXMEX of a sequence is defined as the smallest non-negative integer that does not appear in that sequence. For example, MEX([0,0,1,3])=2MEX⁡([0,0,1,3])=2 and MEX([1,2,2])=0.MEX⁡([1,2,2])=0.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1001≤t≤100). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains exactly two integers nn and qq (4≤n≤1044≤n≤104, 1≤q≤3⋅1051≤q≤3⋅105) — the size of the permutation and the number of ranges, respectively.

The ii-th of the next qq lines contains two integers li,rili,ri (1≤li≤ri≤n1≤li≤ri≤n).

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn and qq do not exceed 104104 and 3⋅1053⋅105 respectively over all test cases.

Additional Constraint: it is guaranteed that no range is repeated in the same test case.

Interaction

To ask a query, output a line in the following format (without the quotes):

  • "? ll rr" (1≤l≤r≤n1≤l≤r≤n)

The jury will return a single integer, the value of MEX([pl,pl+1,…,pr])MEX⁡([pl,pl+1,…,pr]).

When you have found the answer, output a single line in the following format:

  • "! xx" (0≤x≤n0≤x≤n).

After that, proceed to process the next test case or terminate the program if it was the last test case. Printing the answer does not count as a query.

The interactor is not adaptive, meaning that the values of the permutation are known before the participant asks the queries.

If your program makes more than max(300,⌈n2⌉+2)max(300,⌈n2⌉+2) queries, your program should immediately terminate to receive the verdict Wrong Answer. Otherwise, you can get an arbitrary verdict because your solution will continue to read from a closed stream.

After printing a query do not forget to output the end of line and flush the output. Otherwise, you may get the Idleness Limit Exceeded verdict. To do this, use:

  • fflush(stdout) or cout.flush() in C++
  • System.out.flush() in Java;
  • flush(output) in Pascal;
  • stdout.flush() in Python;
  • see the documentation for other languages.

Hacks

For hacks, use the following format.

The first line of the input should contain a single integer tt (1≤t≤1001≤t≤100) — the number of test cases.

The first line of each test case should contain exactly two integers nn and qq (4≤n≤1044≤n≤104, 1≤q≤3⋅1051≤q≤3⋅105) — the size of the permutation and the number of ranges you are given, respectively.

The second line should contain nn integers p1,p2,…,pnp1,p2,…,pn — where pipi is the ii-th element of the permutation. It should hold that pp is a permutation containing integers 00 to n−1n−1.

The ii-th of the next qq lines should contain two integers lili, riri (1≤li≤ri≤n1≤li≤ri≤n).

It should hold that the sum of nn and qq do not exceed 104104 and 3⋅1053⋅105 respectively over all test cases.

Additional Constraint: no range should be repeated in the same test case.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first example, the hidden permutation is p=[0,3,1,2]p=[0,3,1,2] and the ranges are [1,2],[2,4],[1,3][1,2],[2,4],[1,3]. The third range is optimal, as MEX([p1,p2,p3])=MEX([0,3,1])=2MEX⁡([p1,p2,p3])=MEX⁡([0,3,1])=2, which is maximum.

In our first query, we ask about l=1,r=3l=1,r=3 and the judge gives us the value MEX([p1,p2,p3])=2MEX⁡([p1,p2,p3])=2. In the second query, we ask about l=4,r=4l=4,r=4 and the judge gives us the value MEX([p4])=0MEX⁡([p4])=0. Likewise, MEX([p1])=1MEX⁡([p1])=1 and MEX([p1,p2,p3,p4])=4MEX⁡([p1,p2,p3,p4])=4.

Somehow, we figure out that the answer we are looking for is 22.

In the second example, p=[3,5,0,1,4,2]p=[3,5,0,1,4,2].

In the third example, p=[0,1,2,3]p=[0,1,2,3].

Note that this is just an explanation of the way the interaction works and does not show any strategy to solve the problem.

problems.title: Diadrash (Hard Version)
problems.statementHtml:
This is the Hard version of the problem. The difference between the versions is that in this version, you can make at most 3030 queries. You can hack only if you solved all versions of this problem.

This problem is interactive.

There is a permutation∗∗ pp of the integers from 00 to n−1n−1 hidden from you. Additionally, you are given qq ranges [l1,r1],[l2,r2],…,[lq,rq][l1,r1],[l2,r2],…,[lq,rq] where 1≤li≤ri≤n1≤li≤ri≤n.

You need to discover the maximum MEXMEX among the values of pp in the qq ranges that are given to you in the input. Formally, you must discover the value of maxqi=1MEX([pli,pli+1,…,pri])maxi=1qMEX⁡([pli,pli+1,…,pri])††. To do this, you may make at most 3030 queries of the following form:

∗∗A permutation of the integers from 00 to n−1n−1 is a sequence of nn elements where every integer from 00 to n−1n−1 appears exactly once. For example, the sequence [0,3,1,2][0,3,1,2] is a permutation, but the sequence [0,0,2,1][0,0,2,1] is not.

††The MEXMEX of a sequence is defined as the smallest non-negative integer that does not appear in that sequence. For example, MEX([0,0,1,3])=2MEX⁡([0,0,1,3])=2 and MEX([1,2,2])=0.MEX⁡([1,2,2])=0.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1001≤t≤100). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains exactly two integers nn and qq (4≤n≤1044≤n≤104, 1≤q≤3⋅1051≤q≤3⋅105) — the size of the permutation and the number of ranges, respectively.

The ii-th of the next qq lines contains two integers li,rili,ri (1≤li≤ri≤n1≤li≤ri≤n).

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn and qq do not exceed 104104 and 3⋅1053⋅105 respectively over all test cases.

Additional Constraint: it is guaranteed that no range is repeated in the same test case.

Interaction

To ask a query, output a line in the following format (without the quotes):

  • "? ll rr" (1≤l≤r≤n1≤l≤r≤n)

The jury will return a single integer, the value of MEX([pl,pl+1,…,pr])MEX⁡([pl,pl+1,…,pr]).

When you have found the answer, output a single line in the following format:

  • "! xx" (0≤x≤n0≤x≤n).

After that, proceed to process the next test case or terminate the program if it was the last test case. Printing the answer does not count as a query.

The interactor is not adaptive, meaning that the values of the permutation are known before the participant asks the queries.

If your program makes more than 3030 queries, your program should immediately terminate to receive the verdict Wrong Answer. Otherwise, you can get an arbitrary verdict because your solution will continue to read from a closed stream.

After printing a query do not forget to output the end of line and flush the output. Otherwise, you may get the Idleness Limit Exceeded verdict. To do this, use:

  • fflush(stdout) or cout.flush() in C++
  • System.out.flush() in Java;
  • flush(output) in Pascal;
  • stdout.flush() in Python;
  • see the documentation for other languages.

Hacks

For hacks, use the following format.

The first line of the input should contain a single integer tt (1≤t≤1001≤t≤100) — the number of test cases.

The first line of each test case should contain exactly two integers nn and qq (4≤n≤1044≤n≤104, 1≤q≤3⋅1051≤q≤3⋅105) — the size of the permutation and the number of ranges you are given, respectively.

The second line should contain nn integers p1,p2,…,pnp1,p2,…,pn — where pipi is the ii-th element of the permutation. It should hold that pp is a permutation containing integers 00 to n−1n−1.

The ii-th of the next qq lines should contain two integers lili, riri (1≤li≤ri≤n1≤li≤ri≤n).

It should hold that the sum of nn and qq do not exceed 104104 and 3⋅1053⋅105 respectively over all test cases.

Additional Constraint: no range should be repeated in the same test case.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first example, the hidden permutation is p=[0,3,1,2]p=[0,3,1,2] and the ranges are [1,2],[2,4],[1,3][1,2],[2,4],[1,3]. The third range is optimal, as MEX([p1,p2,p3])=MEX([0,3,1])=2MEX⁡([p1,p2,p3])=MEX⁡([0,3,1])=2, which is maximum.

In our first query, we ask about l=1,r=3l=1,r=3 and the judge gives us the value MEX([p1,p2,p3])=2MEX⁡([p1,p2,p3])=2. In the second query, we ask about l=4,r=4l=4,r=4 and the judge gives us the value MEX([p4])=0MEX⁡([p4])=0. Likewise, MEX([p1])=1MEX⁡([p1])=1 and MEX([p1,p2,p3,p4])=4MEX⁡([p1,p2,p3,p4])=4.

Somehow, we figure out that the answer we are looking for is 22.

In the second example, p=[3,5,0,1,4,2]p=[3,5,0,1,4,2].

In the third example, p=[0,1,2,3]p=[0,1,2,3].

Note that this is just an explanation of the way the interaction works and does not show any strategy to solve the problem.

problems.title: Plegma
problems.statementHtml:
This is a run-twice (communication) problem.

There are two players: Player A and Player B. The jury will first interact with player A. After player A ends their interaction, the jury will interact with player B. Note that player A and player B may not directly pass information to each other; both players are only able to send information or receive information from the jury, but they may agree on the strategy they will use to communicate.

The jury has a binary grid GG of nn rows and nn columns (each cell of this grid has value either 00 or 11). Row 11 is the top-most row, and column 11 is the left-most column. The connectivity of this grid is defined as 11 if there is a path going left, right, up, or down going through only cells with value 11 connecting each pair of cells (i1,j1)(i1,j1) and (i2,j2)(i2,j2) with Gi1,j1=Gi2,j2=1Gi1,j1=Gi2,j2=1. Note that moving diagonally is not allowed. It is guaranteed that there exists at least one cell with value of 11 in this grid.

The jury first interacts with player A. The jury will give player A the grid GG. After inspecting the grid, player A must determine two integers rr and cc and send them to the jury. At the start of player B's interaction, player B will receive the values of all cells in the rr'th row and all cells in the cc'th column from the jury. Note that player B is not given the values of rr and cc.

Player A wants to ensure player B can determine the connectivity of GG. Your task is to act as both players and find a strategy so that player B is able to determine the connectivity correctly. Note that the communicator of this task is not adaptive – that is, the grid given to you on the first run will be the same as the grid used to evaluate the connectivity.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Your code will be ran exactly two times on each test. On the first run, you will be Player A, and on the second Player B.

First Run Input

The first line of the input contains the string first. The purpose of this is so your program recognizes that this is its first run, and it should act as Player A.

Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains two integers nn and CC (2≤n≤1000,0≤C≤12≤n≤1000,0≤C≤1) – the size of the grid and the connectivity respectively.

The following nn lines contain information about the grid. The iith of these lines contains a binary string GiGi of length nn, indicating the ii-th row of the grid.

It is guaranteed that:

  • The sum of n2n2 does not exceed 2⋅1062⋅106 over all test cases
  • The value of CC matches with the information in the grid – that is, if C=1C=1, then the grid has connectivity 11, and if C=0C=0, then the grid has connectivity 00.
  • Each grid has at least one 11 in the input.

Second Run Input

The first line of the input contains the string second. The purpose of this is so your program recognizes that this is its second run, and it should act as Player B.

Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows. Note that this number is equal to tt from the first run input.

The first line of each test case contains exactly one integer nn — the size of the grid given on the ii'th test case of the first run input.

The second line of each test case contains a binary string Gr,1Gr,2…Gr,nGr,1Gr,2…Gr,n — the contents in row rr of the grid. Note that the integer rr is sent by player A to the jury at the end of their interaction of the ii'th test case

The third line of each test case contains a binary string G1,cG2,c…Gn,cG1,cG2,c…Gn,c — the contents in column cc of the grid. Note that the integer cc is sent by player A to the jury at the end of their interaction of the ii'th test case.

Hacks

To make hacks, use the following format:

The first line should contain exactly one integer tt (1≤t≤104)(1≤t≤104) — the number of grids. Then, tt blocks of input should follow.

The first line of each block of input must contain a single integer nn (2≤n≤1000)(2≤n≤1000) — the size of the grid the jury will choose.

Each of the next nn lines should contain a binary string of size nn. The ii'th of these lines should contain Gi,1Gi,2…Gi,nGi,1Gi,2…Gi,n — the contents of the ii'th row of the grid the jury will choose.

There must exist at least a single cell with value of 11 in each grid, and the sum of n2n2 over all test cases should not exceed 2⋅1062⋅106.

Note that the connectivity of each grid is determined by the jury, and you do not need to output it for a hack.
problems.outputSpecHtml:
For the first run, for each test case, output two integers rr and cc (1≤r,c≤n1≤r,c≤n). This indicates that you want the second run to receive the rr-th row and the cc-th column of the grid.

For the second run, for each test case, output an integer CC (0≤C≤10≤C≤1) – the connectivity of the grid.
problems.noteHtml:
On the first input example, the first grid is the following:

11
10

On the first run, we know that n=2n=2. After inspecting the example, we can determine that the connectivity is 11.

For the sake of this example, suppose Player A and Player B have agreed to some strategy where if the connectivity is 11, then player A should send a row and a column that both end with 00. In this case, row 22 and column 22 satisfies this strategy. Note that this is an example strategy for the sake of demonstration, and using this strategy will not work for all cases.

Then, take a look at the second run. Now, we are Player B. We receive that n=2n=2 and that the chosen row has values r=[1,0]r=[1,0] and the chosen column has values c=[1,0]c=[1,0]. Since the last number of each row is 00, player B uses the agreed upon strategy to determine that the connectivity is 11.

tutorial.contentHtml:
Comment

B turned out to be harder than expected. I apologize for this, but I hope there are still problems that are fun and educational for you to solve in this round.

Regardless, I hope this round encourages authors to include communication problems in their future rounds, and in earlier positions as well.

Problem A — Souvlaki VS. Kalamaki

Solution

Suppose it Kalamaki's turn on some even round 2k. Kalamaki can swap element a2k with a2k+1. If a2k>a2k+1, he will not swap the elements, but if a2k<a2k+1, he will swap them. In both cases he wins the game, because the array will never be sorted. Therefore, if a2k≠a2k+1, Kalamaki will win no matter what.

Now assume every time Kalamaki plays, the two elements he can swap have the same value, because otherwise we have shown that he wins. Suppose that it is Souvlaki's turn on round 2k+1. We know that a2k=a2k+1 from the previous assumption. If a2k+1>a2k+2, we know that a2k+1=a2k>a2k+2, but he is unable to swap a2k and a2k+2, therefore he loses. Otherwise, if a2k+1≤a2k+2 he will not do anything, and he proceeds to the next round.

From these observations, we see that a is winnable by Souvlaki if and only if: a1≤a2=a3≤a4=a5≤…, or a2≤a1=a3≤a4=a5≤…. It is obvious now that Souvlaki, before the start of the game, will sort a in non-decreasing order. To determine if Souvlaki wins or not it is enough to check the above condition is satisfied after sorting.
